Anonymous Sat 01 Jul 2023 04:09:05 No.57671126 Report
Quoted By: >>57671160 >>57672451 >>57685794
>>57670873
>>57670901
Read chapters 1-4 of SoaSW.
The weird magic fantasy elements are pretty cool and juxtapose well against the more modern elements and apocalypse plot. It's like if Adventure Time was more grounded.
Chapter 1 was a solid opener to the world, if I had any complaint, it would be that Lyka felt a bit passive at points. She's not very proactive throughout the first three chapters, mostly getting led along until chapter 4 where she starts working with Grox and investigates the washing machine. I'd like to see more scenes with her solo, just to get a more rounded view of her.
I think the aborted sex scene in chapter 2 was a mistake. You need to set things up so that they're both satisfying to the reader and make sense chronologically. It's a bit of a stretch, but I can buy that Albert and Lyka could fall in love in a week's time (even with the language barrier basically making it impossible to express complex ideas), they're in a stressful environment in which the only people they can rely on are each other. Fear and anxiety promote attachment.
The problem is that you didn't develop their relationship enough in writing for the sex to feel satisfying in the narrative. They have two scenes near the beginning of the chapter where they're kind of flirting, an interlude where they find some guy's dead body (more on this later) and then the chocolate scene that ends up transitioning into smut. The first time they kiss in writing happens AFTER Albert tries to finger her. How do you get to second base before you take first? You needed at least like two or three more scenes where they developed a more intimate rapport before you got to (attempted) smut.
(1/?)
Anonymous
  • Post

Anonymous Sat 01 Jul 2023 04:11:09 No.57671160 Report
Quoted By: >>57671246 >>57672451
>>57671126
Continuing on with chapter 2:
>This was the first time I had ever seen a dead body in real life.
Has Albert never been to an open-casket funeral? I know you intended this to be a throwaway line, but it's not. Finding a corpse is traumatic, more so if the cause of death was violent, and unless he's desensitized to this kind of thing (experienced soldier, doctor, detective) it's probably going to rattle him pretty bad when it's his first human interaction in weeks.
On the plus side, the fact that he went out of his way to bury the guy shows that he's still holding on to a sense of social decency. I do think that's positive characterization, even if he also did it for the sake of sanitation.
>deadly alien crab thingy
Think about how your word choice affects how the reader interprets your set pieces, as well as how the characters view each other and their environment. The way Albert describes the crab here reads as childish and lacks weight, which doesn't feel right because the thing would have killed him if Lyka wasn't there.
(2/?)

Anonymous Sat 01 Jul 2023 04:14:17 No.57671246 Report
Quoted By: >>57671938 >>57672451
>>57671160
The 3rd chapter was very cute, comic relief feels much more at home since the scenes are low stakes. Very creative designs for aliens, are these original species? Cute closing, I like how Duncan and Albert come from different eras, so there's still variation. Nice little administrative system, you did a good job of making Thrun feel like a lively place.
Chapter 4 is cool, nice to see them getting adjusted to their new community.
The Sneed reference made me giggle. The Missy inclusion made my eyes roll. Both broke my suspension of disbelief, which means the story carries less emotional weight than it did before, and therefore harder to take the characters or their interactions seriously.
>I definitely did not feel like I got eight hours of sleep.
This feels wordy and unconfident, make it punchy and more assertive to give Albert more voice. Like:
>That didn't feel like eight hours of sleep.
or
>No way I got 8 hours of sleep.
Some of the sentence structure in the shower sex scene felt off to me. Could have used another pass to iron things out. Gift scene was cute.
End of chapter 4 is around the point where I started asking "It seems like Albert and Lyka are set up for an easy When is the main conflict going to start?" If you have something set up in chapter 5, consider this criticism moot.
All in all a pretty solid start. Lyka could be a bit more active, and there's some issues with tone especially in Chapter 2, but it's not enough to break the story in my eyes. Good work.

Anonymous Sat 01 Jul 2023 05:10:10 No.57672240 Report
Quoted By: >>57684980
>>57671938
What does the inclusion actually add to the story? Only people who know about Missy and HATSSSSS will get it, all it really does is serve as a weird detour for people who don't. It's a prime example of something you cut from the draft
>writers here have had a tradition of referencing other stories
The only two examples that come to mind are BHA and the shared characters between Altruistic Intent and Roo'd Awakening. BHA is usually a pretty important plot element in the stories that it's featured in, and the recurring characters are part of the agency itself.
Altruistic/Rood's authors are(were?) actively collaborating on the projects together to the point where they wouldn't release updates for one story if they contained information that would spoil a reveal in another.
Both of those require a lot more thought than whatever is going on with Missy.

Anonymous Sat 01 Jul 2023 05:56:28 No.57673003 Report
Quoted By: >>57673049 >>57673307
>>57672451
Duncan says "Look at the city-slicker pullin' up in his fancy german car." That's from the Sneedsons.
>But to say it brings down the entire mood of the story I think is a stretch.
It's not a question of mood, it's about investment.
When a reader starts your story, they're supposed to grow attached to your characters and setting as they learn more about it. With time, the story takes on a life of its own, and the reader becomes immersed in the work. This is usually what you want as a writer, because it's what allows your work to connect with your readers on a deeper level.
However, disbelief can only be suspended as long as a story remains at least somewhat grounded. There are a lot of things that can take a reader out of that desired state of immersion. Typos, inconsistent characterization, forced or crappy politics/morality, and shitty memes all fall into this category. When your story has problems like these, they prevent your reader from fully engaging with the story you have to tell because they send the subconcious message of "the author didn't care enough to fix or change this, so why should I care about that?"
What the inclusion of Missy tells me about your story as a reader is that your primary goal in writing SoaSW is having fun and fucking around by including dumb in-jokes. And there's nothing wrong with that kind of story if that's what you want to tell, but you can't expect anyone else to take it seriously if you aren't.

Anonymous Sat 01 Jul 2023 06:57:02 No.57673974 Report
Quoted By: >>57687514
>>57673307
It isn't a cameo, a cameo would be Missy tapping Albert on the shoulder, thinking it's Leo. When she finds out it isn't she leaves and disappears into the crowd without a word. A weird interaction, but not something so unusual that it detracts from the story, nor something Albert would think about in too much depth.
You instead had Missy "attack" Albert and drop a line in English before disappearing. The implications of a non-human that can communicate in English are pretty huge for Albert, considering he only knows two other people who speak his language, one of whom he had to teach. You wrote it in a way where the event has to have enough significance that it ends up getting mentioned again in a later scene. Now it's an open plot thread, and distracts both the characters and the reader. A mysterious alien that knows English, attacked the narrator, and disappeared warrants investigation.
Regarding Kaktus, you shouldn't cheapen your own work by including one of his characters in a way that doesn't fit your story. It only subtracts from both.
References, cameos and inclusions can all have their places in storytelling. You just make sure you think things through so you don't give them significance that you don't plan to follow up with.

Because the whole story behind Averi and the artist compels me to keep her around as a sort of 'side character' for the thread. Effectively, Averi is dead, but she is around in /hmofa/'s heart.
Also she is racist and I am racist too.
>2. Did you have some sort of profound experience with it during your formative years, have a profound attraction to the character herself or is it merely a fancy because of the aesthetics or some other factor (please specify)?
No. If anything, I was a typical 'furry is le cringe' kid back in the day
>3. Are you only attracted to the one species/character you post or do you enjoy any others?
Oh no, I think most waifur species have a lot of interesting love, romance and sexo opportunities to them. I particularly like felines.
>4. Does the species/character you post represent your waifur ideal? If yes, kindly elaborate why/how.
Kinda. I think Averi's status as a little gremlin that you can't help but love despite the fact she steals your food and acts like a queen is really wholesome and cute.

Anonymous Sat 01 Jul 2023 21:16:01 No.57686816 Report
Quoted By: >>57687004 >>57687181 >>57687333
I wrote the critique, I'm pretty much the only one who publicly posts long form stuff save Review_Anon who appears once in a blue moon.
This is going to sound absolutely cynical but I think the two biggest factors in how much a story is talked about is how much art there is of the characters, and how frequently an author updates. Kaktus is a solid writer and there's a lot to talk about with his projects, but HATSSSSS would not be nearly as dominant of a topic if it wasn't for the fact that he was collaborating with an artist who actively produced art for the character that he could drop in thread. It also helped that he didn't leave too much time in between updates, meaning that his story always stayed in public conscience. That shit is huge, and even if it's not the best thing ever written here, I do think Kaktus deserves massive props for knowing how to shill his stuff well.
If you want people to talk about your writing, pick up your pen or pick up your wallet, or go to the draw request thread and plead over there for someone to make something nice for you. And write shit in advance so you always have a backlog of work to post.

Anonymous Sat 01 Jul 2023 21:52:40 No.57687725 Report
Quoted By: >>57688057
>>57687333
checked. Better get started building that cult of personality, dude.
It may help your motivation if you view your stories as a business you're building up. At first no one knows who you are and maybe no one cares. In this phase it doesn't matter how good you are at writing, but as you keep writing and putting out material you build credibility and renown. Then people come to expect that material from you, and they will come to you for it. Having some sort of consistency is key to what you desire. Knowing that you are improving your craft at all, assuming you enjoy writing, should be enough to carry you in the beginning, even if you are getting little to no feedback.

Well, All I can say is that your own work isn't going to become more popular just because you loudly hate whoever is more popular than you.

I am actually worried he is trying to patronize me. I gauge it's readership by Kudos, of which there is sixty, versus its seventeen-hundred hits/clicks.
If sixty people hit the "like" button, then that's more than I ever could have hoped for.
So I just opened HATSSSSS, and saw that it now has one-thousand kudos and seventy-seven-thousand hits/clicks. It has all this art, both pre-existing and later-produced, some of it meme-tier garbage and other parts of it very serious; I'm not jealous or angry.
I'm envious. I want that and I have to work for it.
He's been writing longer than me, has more internet friends than me, has a huge pile of art for fuel.
I've got a coming of age story about a narrow-minded pervert learning to grow up and be a man, and two pieces of fan art drawn by artists who as far as I know have never even read my shit.
I'm not even "competing" with Kaktus. I don't plan on making it a competition. I'm gonna do my thing and I'll either succeed or I'll crash and burn.

And maybe that's all this is. You and me are just two completely different people, unable to look at this situation the same way.

And that's okay. Have a nerdy griffon.

Anonymous Sat 01 Jul 2023 22:54:06 No.57689029 Report
Quoted By: >>57689043 >>57689135
>>57688666
I think it's possible satan. Not to sound like I huff my own farts, but I'd argue the fact this thread exists at all is a result/representation of the current social climate and the culture we live in. A window into how certain people have reacted to certain societal pressures and stimuli. Sometime in the future historians may study this thread or the texts it has produced. This place is a snapshot of our times and the people who lived in it.

So, if someone in this thread were to elevate themselves to the point of being an excellent and renowned author and then wrote a hmofa style story with the goal of appealing to a normie and intellectual audience. That story could possibly become something like what Huckleberry Finn is: a window into how people lived and what those times were like. I think that's what a lot of intellectual literature is like: rock solid writing, an interesting plot, a window into the culture of those times and it usually ends with a positive message.

Anonymous Sat 01 Jul 2023 23:11:35 No.57689365 Report
Quoted By: >>57689482
>>57689055
>I hate writing
That really is the paradox. Writing takes a lot of work, there are many times where I have to write boring sections I'm not interested it, but is necessary for the plot. It just comes with the territory, so I haven't got any advice for that.

Something to keep in mind is that you're still learning, so not everything you write is going to be perfect. The fact you said I struggle to come up with "good ideas" tells me you have ideas, but you assume people won't like them. I'm still learning myself, but generally I try to keep some disconnect with my stories. If you get too married to one of your stories, you won't be able to accept any feedback on it that people will provide and it'll drag you down. I know people say this a lot, but you should just write. Work on the new one and see where it takes you. If you end up failing, you will learn something from the experience and the next story will be better. If you really like the old one, everything you have written is not going anywhere, you're not throwing it away. As you improve your writing abilities, you'll be able to go back to it at any time and give it the attention you want to.
Anonymous

Anonymous Sat 01 Jul 2023 23:36:59 No.57689908 Report

>not enough constructive feedback
I can sympathize, I think every writefag here suffers from this issue. My stories are somewhat popular and even I have difficulty acquiring constructive feedback. Most of the feedback I get is "I liked this", with no elaboration, as well. I'll tell you what I tell everyone that has this issue: post your story in as many places as it is relevant. Yes, this means posting it on reddit, as horrible as it is, and in other threads you can find. I do it, and it does get me more feedback.

Another thing you can do is watch videos on writing. Chances are, you have a vague idea of what you need to work on, so look up videos on advice from popular authors. George R.R Martin has gone to many conventions and you can find many recordings of him talking about writing on youtube, as an example.

Anonymous Sun 02 Jul 2023 00:31:29 No.57691075 Report
Quoted By:
>I'm gonna repost this in the next thread to continue the discussion.
>>57690798
For both of those things you said, I think that's the benefit of the anonymity that 4chan provides.
When you receive feedback on 4chan, you have no idea who it who the hell it comes from. It could be a random autist or is could be from an English professor. It's up to the writer whether to use that feedback and how to incorporate it, if they decide to. Whether its incorporated should be based on the merit of the feedback, not by who is posting the feedback. I'd argue we should never use tripcodes when giving feedback for that reason.

If you're a popular author giving feedback to a guy who's barely written, you don't want to have that big of a pull on their decision making because then they are writing the story you think they should be writing and not what they want to be writing. At the same time if you're an inexperienced author giving advice to an experienced one, hiding behind that anonymity makes it easier to offer your genuine thoughts without fear of it being attached to you if you end up looking like an idiot, or the author doesn't like it.
Anonymous
